awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2: Holocene glacier length variations along the spine of the American Cordilleras and their climatic significance
awd_abstract_narration:
The worldwide retreat of glaciers over the past century is one of the clearest signals of global warming, but it raises two basic questions that remain hazy: how anomalous are current glacier extents, and what were long-term glacier trends prior to the industrial era? This project will reconstruct how often during the Holocene (the last 11,000 years) a dozen glaciers down the length of the Americas, from the Arctic to Patagonia, were larger versus smaller than today. We take a community-based approach to reduce cost, with active glacier scientists collecting samples gratis during their own field campaigns to contribute to this project. Our results will provide a geologic lens through which to view modern climate change, and offer a paleo-test for computer models used to simulate glacier responses to future warming -- important to freshwater resources in some areas and global sea level rise. 


We will reconstruct glacier histories by applying the in situ 14C-10Be chronometer to several samples of proglacial bedrock at each glacier terminus. This technique is able to determine what portion of the Holocene a glacier advanced beyond and retreated behind its current terminus by quantifying the buildup of both 14C and 10Be during periods of exposure and the preferential loss of 14C during episodes of ice cover due to its much shorter half-life. Our latitudinal transect is designed to maximize understanding of how glaciers responded to orbital variations, as well as how climate may have been coupled between the low and high latitudes and across the hemispheres. Given that Holocene glacier trends may have varied substantially with latitude, the broad scale of our reconstructions will also provide the context needed for evaluating current glacier retreat around the world.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Nearly all glaciers in the world have retreated over the past century, and this retreat has accelerated in recent decades. But it is generally unclear how large recent glacier retreat is compared to the range of natural fluctuations over previous millennia. Have glaciers already shrunk to their smallest sizes of the Holocene interglacial period (the last 11,000 years)?

We collected 69 samples of recently exposed bedrock in front of a dozen glaciers spanning the Americas, from Alaska to Patagonia. The concentrations of rare nuclides, beryllium-10 and carbon-14, in these rocks provide a signal of how much time in the past the bedrock was covered by ice or exposed; in other words, how much of the past the nearby glacier was larger or smaller than today. Nearly all glaciers are now smaller than they have been in millennia, though there is regional variation in the amount of relative retreat. In the Northern Hemisphere, glaciers have retreated to their smallest extent in 1,000-2,000 years up to more than 11,000 years. This range may partly reflect differences in how quickly the glaciers have responded to recent climate change. In contrast, most glaciers from the tropics and Southern Hemisphere are already smaller than they have been throughout the past 11,000 years. Our results also support a well-established pattern of prehistoric glacier trends in the Northern Hemisphere in which glaciers were relatively small 10,000-5,000 years ago but expanded thereafter due to gradual changes in Earth?s tilt and orbit. We found a similar pattern of long-term glacier growth (prior to modern retreat) in the tropics, suggesting tropical and Northern Hemisphere climates may have been linked over the Holocene.

This project trained four graduate students, and built a team of a dozen glacier scientists working across the length of the Americas. Results have been shared in multiple publications. These findings highlight the extraordinary nature of modern glacier retreat and suggest that climate change in some regions has already reached a level unprecedented in human history.
